conclusion: To find the coefficient of friction (μ) and the angle (θ), we need to analyze the forces acting on the suitcase when it is being pulled.
The suitcase can be either pushed or pulled on the ground.
The total mass of the suitcase is 15 kg, and the gravitational acceleration is 10 m/s².
The minimum value of the pull is 90 N, and the angle between the pull and the horizontal direction is θ.
The resistance of the suitcase to the ground is proportional to the supporting force of the ground, with the ratio being μ.
The suitcase is being pulled with an oblique upward pull to do uniform movement on the horizontal ground.
The gravitational force acting on the suitcase is 150 N (acting downwards).
The pulling force is 90 N (acting at an angle θ to the horizontal).

premise: Resolve the pulling force into components
conclusion: Horizontal component (P_x) = P * cos(θ), Vertical component (P_y) = P * sin(θ)

premise: Apply Newton's second law for horizontal motion
conclusion: P_x - F_f = 0 (since the suitcase is moving at a constant velocity)

premise: Apply Newton's second law for vertical motion

conclusion: P_x = 90 N * cos(θ), P_y = 90 N * sin(θ), W = 150 N
N = W - P_y = 150 N - 90 N * sin(θ)

premise: Substitute the normal force into the frictional force equation
conclusion: F_f = μ * N, 90 N * cos(θ) = μ * (150 N - 90 N * sin(θ))
